My Granddad was one of the greatest minds to me but sadly his mind was lost many years before his body was lost two years ago. Every week when he visited he would always ask me what I was doing in science and maths, and at the time I was in primary school so really wasn't doing much in either but he would still listen attentively. Even towards the end of his Alzheimer's when I mentioned I had just started learning differentiation his face lit up and he recited "dx by dy".  My biggest regret is that the man who encouraged me to pursue science and maths is no longer here to see me fulfil our dream.

big thanks to you for thinking to include Koko. i watched 'Koko, le gorille qui parle' (1978) and rewatched 'Project Nim' (2011) after some vids on Eons inspired me to revisit my passion for all things ape and primate. can recommend both documentaries hgihly. together they give very comprehensive perspective into the area of study, positive and negatives (to learn from).

Lest anyone be confused, that isn't how hawking radiation works.  For one thing, it is just as likely that the matter particle of the pair would be drawn into the black hole, for another, the energy from the annihilation ADDS to the mass of the black hole (since M=E/c^2).
Although I don't reject their contribution, but this lists exclusively focuses on United States. What about other countries?

Not sure how I feel about including Koko. Patterson's work with gorillas has been widely disputed and has come under attack for likely being a combination of operant conditioning (Koko only made signs because she knew she'd get treats) and the Clever Hans effect (trainers subconsciously giving Koko cues for what to sign). Most of the stuff Hank said here are claims directly from Patterson herself- there's very little peer reviewed data on Koko's actual language ability, and the stuff that is out there makes much more modest claims. The "Queen" bit strikes me as particularity improbable.

When Hawking described Hawking radiation in "A Brief History of Time" using the pair particle anti-particle thing he also said "don't take this picture too seriously" for a reason: it's pretty, it's easy, but it's not accurate. Hawking radiation is closer to the Casimir effect than to pair generation. And yes, it's complicated. The team of "PBS Space Time" did a good job explaining it, but it took them several episodes.

Koko's answer is very intriguing.
Is it known whether it was clear to her that the question meant " Where do animals go after death" and not "[...] to die"?
It sounds like she wanted to find a comfortable place to lie down and slowly fade away...but that doesn't answer if she had any concept of afterlife or understanding of what happens to a dead body.
That's what I think: Animals don't have an idea of afterlife because in the wild, you don't get any sense of that. Your dead relatives rot in your vicinity, being eaten up by the ecosystem around you and of which you're a vital part. How does some magical place like heaven fit into that life?
I also would like to follow up with "Do humans develop a concept of afterlife as young kids and by themselves?" because if they do, my point would be weakened ^^

One thing that Stephen Hawking also gave science, which often goes overlooked because he just had ALS and wasn’t a medical professional, is how much information he gave doctors about ALS. Most people don’t live very long after the diagnosis and his condition gave doctors many insights about how the disease progresses in a way that could prove very helpful for finding treatments.

I’m in college right now studying engineering, and as I grow older and venture further into the scientific world, I can only hope to have a tiny fraction of the insight and appreciation for the universe that these three have displayed. Rest in peace.
Can I get a RIP in the chat

Aloha SciShow! Before Ruth Gates passed away, she was witness to Hawaii passing SB 2571 into law. This law states that; the chemicals in Oxybenzone, and Octinoxate , " have significant harmful impacts on Hawaii's marine environment and residing ecosystems. " The legislation aims to keep sunscreens that contain those chemicals off store shelves, however those products would still be available to those who have a prescription. I have seen the coral reefs in Hawaii go from alive & thriving in the 60's & 70's to looking like a desert, just brown rock & sand at popular beaches now. A good example of how a reef can begin to heal is here on Kauai at Ke'e beach on our north shore. Catastrophic flooding closed the highway there in April of this year. The locals have never seen such a resurgence of fish & corals, this was noticed after only 4 months, that good news also, I imagine Ruth Gates  was witness to before passing.  R.I.P. to all 3 of these great minds.
